head.title: In a Concrete City, Dreams of Light and Air

hedline.hl1: In a Concrete City, Dreams of Light and Air

Re ''In City Canyons, Slivers of Public Space Erode'' (front page, Sept. 28):

The study of public plazas in New York City provides proof that over time, commercial interests, like building owners and restaurant operations, encroach on public space. The solution to this problem is enforcement of existing regulations, as is now under way.

Yet the proposal by the Department of City Planning to amend our zoning regulations seeks to eliminate plazas from all new residential buildings. It would require new buildings to be constructed with continuous walls looming over the sidewalk.

In a densely packed city like ours, where people are desperate for patches of light and air, and perhaps a few benches or chairs, public plazas provide an important amenity and require only appropriate enforcement to make them truly available to the public.
MICHAEL D. UTEVSKY New York, Sept. 29, 2000
The writer is chairman of the land use and zoning committee, Manhattan Community Board 5.
